H0.text: Domains are the least specific grouping, and all organisms can be classified into one of the three domains.

H1.text: Aspects are the least specific grouping into which all organisms can be classified, and all organisms belong to one of three aspects.

H2.text: Phlylum is one of the three least specific groupings into which all organisms can be classified.

H3.text: Species is one of three least specific groupings into which all organisms can be classified.

A4.text: Each of these three domains contains unique ribosomal RNA.

A5.text: The eocyte hypothesis, proposed by Lake et al. (1984), which posits two domains, Bacteria and Archaea, with Eukaryota included as a subordinate clade branching from Archaea.

A6.text: The three-domain system is a taxonomic classification system that groups all cellular life into three domains, namely Archaea, Bacteria and Eukarya, introduced by Carl Woese, Otto Kandler and Mark Wheelis in 1990.

A7.text: The three-domain hypothesis is considered obsolete by some who believe that eukaryotes do not form a separate domain of life, but arose from a fusion between an Archaea species and a Bacteria species.

A8.text: Biological classification uses taxonomic ranks, including among others (in order from most inclusive to least inclusive): domain, kingdom, phylum, class, order, family, genus, species, and strain.

A9.text: His 2004 classification treated the archaeobacteria as part of a subkingdom of the kingdom Bacteria, i.e., he rejected the three-domain system entirely.

A10.text: Most importantly, the trees that they generate are not necessarily correct â€“ they do not necessarily accurately represent the evolutionary history of the included taxa.

A11.text: Understanding of the oldest branchings in the tree of life only developed substantially with DNA sequencing, leading to a system of domains rather than kingdoms as top level rank being put forward by Carl Woese, Otto Kandler, and Mark Wheelis in 1990, uniting all the eukaryote kingdoms in the domain 'Eucarya'.

A12.text: The leading evolutionary theory is they were created by symbiogenesis between an anaerobic Promethearchaeota archaeon and an aerobic proteobacterium, which formed the mitochondria.
